13.76.text: I am going to start with a challenge.

16.04.text: I want you to imagine each of these two scenes

18.83.text: in as much detail as you can.

25.93.text: Well, who are the people who are giving a hearty welcome?

39.72.text: What expressions are on their faces?

41.98.text: What are they wearing and drinking?

44.75.text: Fix these pictures in your mind's eye

47.11.text: and then jot down a sentence or two to describe them.

50.13.text: We'll come back to them later.

57.67.text: the Celts in Britain were ruled by Romans.

60.52.text: This had one benefit for the Celts:

62.99.text: the Romans protected them from the barbarian Saxon tribes

68.38.text: But then the Roman Empire began to crumble,

70.68.text: and the Romans withdrew from Britain.

73.70.text: With the Romans gone, the Germanic tribes,

75.92.text: the Angles, Saxons, Jutes, and Frisians

82.75.text: and formed kingdoms in the British Isles.

85.48.text: For several centuries, these tribes lived in Britain,

88.29.text: and their Germanic language, Anglo Saxon,

91.41.text: became the common language, what we call Old English.

95.79.text: Although modern English speakers may think Old English sounds like a different language,

100.94.text: if you look and listen closely, you'll find many words that are recognizable.

106.66.text: For example, here is what the Lord's Prayer looks like in Old English.

111.02.text: At first glance, it may look unfamiliar,

113.51.text: but update the spelling a bit,

115.09.text: and you'll see many common English words.

118.87.text: So the centuries passed with Britains happily speaking Old English,

123.52.text: but in the 700's, a series of Viking invasions began,

126.79.text: which continued until a treaty split the island in half.

131.19.text: On one side were the Saxons.

133.28.text: On the other side were the Danes

135.41.text: who spoke a language called Old Norse.

138.52.text: As Saxons fell in love with their cute Danish neighbors

143.57.text: Old Norse mixed with Old English,

146.25.text: and many Old Norse words like

152.05.text: are still a part of our language.

157.36.text: the Norman conquest brought war again to the British Isles.

161.38.text: The Normans were Vikings who settled in France.

163.96.text: They had abandoned the Viking language and culture

166.81.text: in favor of a French lifestyle,

168.96.text: but they still fought like Vikings.

171.09.text: They placed a Norman king on the English throne

173.60.text: and for three centuries, French was the language of the British royalty.

178.27.text: Society in Britain came to have two levels:

185.74.text: The French also brought many Roman Catholic clergymen with them

189.08.text: who added Latin words to the mix.

193.23.text: as thousands of words flowed in,

195.79.text: many having to do with government, law, and aristocracy.

206.45.text: English speakers quickly realized what to do

208.43.text: if they wanted to sound sophisticated:

211.12.text: they would use words that had come from French or Latin.

214.38.text: Anglo Saxon words seemed so plain

216.61.text: like the Anglo Saxon peasants who spoke them.

219.83.text: Let's go back to the two sentences you thought about earlier.

223.24.text: When you pictured the hearty welcome,

225.26.text: did you see an earthy scene with relatives hugging and talking loudly?

231.21.text: Were they wearing lumberjack shirts and jeans?

234.16.text: And what about the cordial reception?

236.76.text: I bet you pictured a far more classy and refined crowd.

245.07.text: How is it that phrases that are considered just about synonymous by the dictionary

249.26.text: can evoke such different pictures and feelings?

258.91.text: The connotation of nobility and authority has persisted

272.09.text: Even if you never heard this history before,

275.39.text: the memory of it persists in the feelings evoked

281.15.text: On some level, it's a story you already knew

284.87.text: because whether we realize it consciously

289.21.text: our history lives in the words we speak and hear.
